questions.text: A 10 years boy presents to you with sexual maturity rating 5, height age > chronological age, hyperpigmentation, short stature and BP 180/110mmHg. Which enzyme is deficient in this condition:

options.label: D
options.text: Cholesterol side chain cleavage enzyme deficiency

questions.explanation:
Solution:

11 beta hydroxylase deficiency This clinical presentation is most consistent with 11 beta hydroxylase deficiency.

Highyeild:

11-Beta Hydroxylase Deficiency 11-beta hydroxylase deficiency is a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) caused by a deficiency in the enzyme 11-beta hydroxylase, which is responsible for the conversion of 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol and 11-deoxycorticosterone to corticosterone in the adrenal glands. Clinical Presentation Precocious puberty (sexual maturity rating of 5 in a 10-year-old boy) Accelerated growth (height age greater than chronological age) Hyperpigmentation Short stature Hypertension (BP 180/110 mmHg) Pathophysiology In 11-beta hydroxylase deficiency, the lack of 11-beta hydroxylase enzyme leads to the accumulation of 11-deoxycortisol and 11-deoxycorticosterone. These precursors are shunted towards the androgen biosynthetic pathway, resulting in excess production of androgens, which causes the clinical manifestations of precocious puberty, accelerated growth, and hyperpigmentation. The accumulation of 11-deoxycorticosterone can also lead to hypertension .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. 21 Alpha Hydroxylase Deficiency causes adrenal insufficiency and excess androgens; leads to virilization and precocious puberty but typically does not cause hypertension. Option: C. 3 Beta Dehydrogenase Deficiency results in a lack of all steroid hormones, leading to adrenal crisis and ambiguous genitalia. Would not cause precocious puberty or hypertension. Option: D. Cholesterol Side Chain Cleavage Enzyme Deficiency Features : Blocks all steroid hormone production, causing severe adrenal insufficiency and hypotension. Would lead to hypotension, not hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following are CORRECT regarding febrile seizure: Simple febrile seizures are generalized tonic and clonic seizures not lasting more than 15 minutes, occurring in children with fever of 38 degrees between 6 months to 5 years and only once in 24 hours. Chance of recurrence after one episode of febrile seizure is 54% Long term anticonvulsants are not indicated in simple febrile seizures CT is indicated in patients in whom there is high risk of structural abnormalities, metabolic disturbances within the age of 3 years Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A, C, D A, C, D is indeed the correct answer. A: Correctly defines simple febrile seizures. C: Correctly states that long-term anticonvulsants are generally not needed for simple febrile seizures. D: Correctly indicates when a CT scan might be considered for a child with a febrile seizure.

Highyeild:

Febrile Seizures Febrile seizures are convulsions associated with an elevated temperature greater than 38 degrees Celsius in children 6 months to 5 years of age. They occur in 2 to 4 % of children younger than 5 years old and are slightly more common in males. We subdivide febrile seizures into simplex and complex febrile seizures. Simple Febrile Seizures are considered simple if they are generalized seizures that last less than 15 minutes and do not recur within a 24-hour period. Complex Febrile Seizure are considered complex, if any of the following occur: they are focal seizures, last longer than 15 minutes, or occur more than once in a 24-hour period. Causes: Febrile seizures are more commonly due to viral infections than bacterial (HHV-6 being the most commonly associated viral illness), they tend to occur early in the illness, and no explicit work-up is mandated but rather testing is patient-specific.

questions.text: A 15 year old boy presents with short stature. On examination, his Upper segment/ Lower segment ratio is 0.8:1. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia A 15-year-old boy with short stature and an upper segment/lower segment ratio of 0.8:1 is spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia.

Highyeild:

Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia Disproportionate short stature demonstrating progressive involvement of the spine and epiphyses of the long bones. The congenita (SEDC) type is present at birth whereas the milder tarda (SEDT) type presents later in childhood. Clinical features: Short trunk, rhizomelic and mesomelic dwarfism, Cervical spine instability (may cause myelopathy or respiratory problems), Barrel chest Hip flexion contractures with associated lumbar lordosis, Coxa vara Genu valgum Congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV), The epiphyseal deformity predisposes to premature osteoarthritis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Achondroplasia: Achondroplasia is the most common form of dwarfism, characterized by disproportionate short stature with a normal-sized trunk and short limbs. In achondroplasia, the upper segment/lower segment ratio is typically greater than 1:1, as the limbs are disproportionately short compared to the trunk. Option: C. Growth hormone deficiency: Growth hormone deficiency can cause short stature, but it typically results in proportionate short stature, where both the upper and lower segments are equally affected. The upper segment/lower segment ratio in growth hormone deficiency is usually within the normal range (0.85-1.05:1). Option: D. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism can also cause short stature, but it is usually accompanied by other symptoms such as fatigue, cold intolerance, and constipation. Hypothyroidism does not typically result in disproportionate short stature.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in nutritional rickets?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Urine calcium: creatinine ratio > 15 In nutritional rickets, the following are typically observed: low phosphorus levels, normal calcium levels, and high parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels due to secondary hyperparathyroidism. Urine calcium: creatinine ratio greater than 15 is not characteristic of nutritional rickets ; this finding is more indicative of conditions with increased renal calcium excretion, not typically seen in nutritional rickets.

Solution:

Respiratory distress syndrome INSURE (Intubation-Surfactant-Extubation) is primarily used in the management of Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS) in premature infants.

Highyeild:

INSURE is primarily used for managing RDS in preterm infants. RDS is a common respiratory condition in premature babies caused by a lack of surfactant that helps keep the alveoli open. The INSURE technique helps deliver surfactant directly to the lungs, improving lung function and reducing the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation. The INSURE strategy: established benefits of surfactant, while avoiding prolonged MV*8 Extubation should be performed when the infant is stable at the discretion of the clinician Early rescue INSURE strategy following nCPAP failure may help avoid potential for respiratory insufficiency and the need for subsequent MV" In studies, early rescue INSURE strategy (FIO2 ≤0.45) was associated with improved outcomes vs late selective therapy (FiO2 >0.45) Rapid extubation after surfactant administration may not be achievable or desirable in the most immature infants, and decisions to extubate should be individualized

questions.text: What is the ideal maintenance fluid in children?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

‘5% dextrose + normal saline 5% dextrose: Provides a source of energy for the child. Normal saline: Maintains electrolyte balance and prevents hyponatremia or hypernatremia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. 10% dextrose + N/2 saline: This is too concentrated and can lead to hyperglycemia. Option: C. 5% dextrose + N/4 saline: This is too hypotonic and can lead to hyponatremia. Option: D. 5% dextrose + N/5 saline: This is also too hypotonic and can lead to hyponatremia.

questions.text: Which of the following MRI findings will be seen in a child with spastic quadriplegia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Multicystic encephalomalacia Severe brain injury leading to spastic quadriplegia, multicystic encephalomalacia can indeed be a significant MRI finding.

Highyeild:

Multicystic encephalomalacia is a sequela of diffuse hypoxic-ischaemic insult of the brain It is commonly characterised by atrophic expansion of the ventricles with intact ventricular walls, multiple cysts of different sizes involving the cerebral white matter, the cerebellar hemispheres, and the spinal cord is usually spared apart from Wallerian degeneration of the corticospinal tracts.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Basal Ganglia Calcifications: Often associated with congenital infections or metabolic disorders, but not typically a direct cause of spastic quadriplegia. Option: B. Periventricular Leukomalacia (PVL): While PVL is common in preterm infants and can lead to spastic diplegia, it is not the primary finding in cases of severe brain injury leading to spastic quadriplegia. Option: C. Cerebellar Degeneration: More associated with ataxic cerebral palsy rather than spastic quadriplegia.
